results.title: Yves Saint Laurent: Valentino
results.creator_credit: Nicolas H Charney, Marlene McGinnis Cardin and Videofashion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Designers”.
Yves Saint Laurent: Follows the career of renowned French designer Yves Saint Laurent, heralding him as the master of modern couture. The course of fashion was set by Saint Laurent as he became one of the first designers to allow the streets to bear direct influence on his collections. Runway shows from throughout the designer’s career, from his heading of Dior at the age of just 22, to the late ‘90’s, illustrate the longevity of his signature pieces, such as the controversial see-through blouse. Saint Laurent’s long association with French actress Catherine Deneuve is highlighted in interviews and photography. Other interviews include those with the designer himself, and with Jean Loup Sieff and Phillip Miller. “Valentino”: Extensive interviews with the Italian designer Valentino reveal his design philosophy and his beginnings at the age of seventeen. Working for Jean Desse and then Guy Laroche, Valentino quickly established a reputation for himself as a talented designer of women’s fashion. At the time of production the designer’s business was generating $600 million a year in couture and associated lines such as fragrances and accessories. The signatures of the Valentino design are explored, including his all white collections, his prominent use of black and white and the bow. Interviews with a plethora of celebrities including Christy Turlington, Sophia Loren, Sylvester Stallone, Bette Midler and Brooke Shields culminate in a review of the 1991 Park Avenue Armory Valentino exhibition. Valentino is portrayed as a ‘slave to perfection’, and the unchallenged leader of Italian fashion.

results.title: Giorgio Armani: Calvin Klein
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Reeder, Marlene McGinnis Cardin and Videofashion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Designers”.
A fascinating documentary focusing on two of fashions most sought-after designers. Giorgio Armani is regarded as one of fashion’s master tailors, and was also one of the first designers to actively seek patronage from Hollywood, coming to prominence after Richard Gere wore an Armani blazer in the film American Gigolo. As a result, the name Armani is synonymous with wealth, elegance and prestige. Calvin Klein, on the other hand, is more famous as a brand name and an image. Klein became a household name after launching a brand of designer jeans, with a controversial advertising campaign featuring a young Brooke Shields. His simple yet appealing designs and lack of interest in adopting seasonal trends have helped him to build a successful billion dollar business.

results.title: The Greatest designers: Paris: Karl Lagerfeld
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Reeder, Marlene McGinnis Cardin and Videofashion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Designers”.
The Greatest Designers: Paris focusses on the work and influence of a selection of French fashion designers, including Chanel, Paul Poiret, Jacques Firth, Elsa Schiaparelli, Cristobal Balenciaga, Hubert de Givenchy, Emanuel Ungaro, Andre Courreges, Pierre Cardin, and Thierry Mugler. Karl Lagerfeld, considered one of the most prolific designers of the twentieth century, is renouned for both his highly-priced ready-to-wear fashion and his philosophical quotes on the business of fashion designing. His designs, capable of turning any woman into a star, are mostly light and fluid in their construction. He worked in couture as an assistant for several years before becoming a freelance designer, which ultimately led him to developing his own signature line, as well as designing for Fendi, Chloe, and Chanel. In the 1980’s, Lagerfeld was responsible for rejuvenating the Chanel label by adapting the Chanel suit and re-working it in weird and wonderful ways.

results.title: Gianni Versace. Givenchy
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Reeder, Adam Falk, Jessica Ramer, Lida Piompino and Video Fashion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Designers”.
This episode of “The Designers” series focuses on Gianni Versace and Hubert de Givenchy, two fashion designers who have had untold influence on fashion design in the twentieth century. Their designs affected not only the rich and famous who wore their creations but also the general public who were undoubtedly influenced by their sense of style. “Gianni Versace: Tragedy and Triumph” was made not long after Versace’s death in Miami. It includes interviews with Versace as well as comments from other designers, fashion industry people and celebrities who wore his clothes. The episode also looks at the retrospective exhibition of Versace’s creations at the New York Metropolitan Museum of Art, organised after Versace’s death by Donatella Versace and the museum. “Givenchy: Timeless Elegance” looks at Givenchy’s career which has spanned more than four decades. In particular it shows how the combination of Givenchy’s elegant designs and the charm of his muse/model Audrey Hepburn entranced the world. Includes interviews with Givenchy, Hepburn and fashion industry people as well as admirers of Givenchy’s clothes.

results.title: Don Bradman: 87 not out
results.brief_description: Born in Cootamundra, New South Wales on 27 August 1908, Don Bradman was eventually to become an Australian icon, and a somewhat reluctant hero. His family moved to Bowral when he was only two years old and he was educated at the local Bowral Elementary School, focusing on sport rather than an academic life. Without any formal coaching, Don Bradman soon found he had a special talent as a batsman when at the age of 12 he played for the senior school team and scored 115 not out. He has played in 52 test matches and scored a total of 6,996 runs, the highest scorer ever. This documentary provides an insight into this quiet unassuming person who dislikes publicity and giving interviews. Interviewed by Ray Martin, Sir Donald Bradman talks of his background, his family and of course his amazing cricketing career, providing anecdotal stories of some of the more memorable occasions such as the Bodyline series in Adelaide in 1933. The interview is interspersed with archival footage and still photographs of past test matches, tours, famous faces such as Harold Larwood, Frank Tyson, Gary Sobers and Dennis Lillee, and brief glimpses of his personal life including his wife and family. A most interesting history of cricket from a frank and honest point of view by one of the game’s highly respected players - and in his words, “Cricket is a glorious game” (Sir Donald Bradman died on 25 February 2001 at the age of 92). “Don Bradman” composed and performed by John Williamson.

results.title: Donna Karan. Vivienne Westwood
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Reeder, Lida Piompino, Michelle Brown, Yana Gould and Video Fashion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Designers”.
Donna Karan: U.S. designer Donna Karan discusses the trademarks of her signature brand and DKNY - luxury, comfort, sensuality, strength and femininity to create a timeless look that transcends any fashion trends - defined by the narrator as a combination of modern luxury and American sensibility. Karan’s history as a designer is covered, as well as interviews with fashion magazine editors, models, fans and photographers. “Vivienne Westwood”: Britain’s most controversial designer is undoubtedly Vivienne Westwood, a designer who attracts responses such as innovative, controversial, sexy and unorthodox. Westwood - normally reticent about discussing issues such as fashion talks about her relationship with Malcolm MacLaren in the 70’s, the breakup and change in focus to the deconstruction of garments, and her passion for the 17-19th centuries. Like the section on Donna Karan, the narrator attempts to capture the tenets of Westwood’s design and looks at areas such as the corset, platform shoes, distorting the female form and symbols of bondage. Both feature plenty of catwalk footage of the designs in action.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rebecca Reeder, Lida Piompino, Michelle Brown, Yana Gould and Video Fashion

Episode of Series “The Designers”.
Donna Karan: U.S. designer Donna Karan discusses the trademarks of her signature brand and DKNY - luxury, comfort, sensuality, strength and femininity to create a timeless look that transcends any fashion trends - defined by the narrator as a combination of modern luxury and American sensibility. Karan’s history as a designer is covered, as well as interviews with fashion magazine editors, models, fans and photographers. “Vivienne Westwood”: Britain’s most controversial designer is undoubtedly Vivienne Westwood, a designer who attracts responses such as innovative, controversial, sexy and unorthodox. Westwood - normally reticent about discussing issues such as fashion talks about her relationship with Malcolm MacLaren in the 70’s, the breakup and change in focus to the deconstruction of garments, and her passion for the 17-19th centuries. Like the section on Donna Karan, the narrator attempts to capture the tenets of Westwood’s design and looks at areas such as the corset, platform shoes, distorting the female form and symbols of bondage. Both feature plenty of catwalk footage of the designs in action.

results.title: Don't call me girlie
results.creator_credit: Andree Wright, Stewart Young and Hilary Furlong
results.brief_description: A survey of the role of women in Australian cinema from the beginning to 1940 using interviews and archival footage. Prominence is given to the collaboration between Lottie Lyell and Raymond Longford, the McDonagh sisters (whose 1933 production Two Minutes Silence was the last Australian feature directed by a woman until My Brilliant Career in 1979) and the careers of actresses Louise Lovely, Helen Twelvetrees and Shirley Ann Richards. Includes extracts from “A Girl of the Bush” (1921), “The Cheaters” (1929), “The Squatter’s Daughter” (1933), “The Silence of Dean Maitland” (1937) and “Dad and Dave Come To Town” (1938).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andree Wright, Stewart Young and Hilary Furlong

results.title: Don's Party
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Phillip Adams and Art House Productions
results.brief_description: Bruce Beresford’s classic Australian comedy exposes Australian social mores in the suburbs. Don and Kath have invited a group of friends to celebrate what they believe will be a Labor Party victory on Election night. The night begins happily enough until the guests receive the news that Labor is losing. Old enmities erupt as hostilities break out amongst the guests as the party disintegrates into an alcoholic disaster. Cast includes Ray Barrett, Graham Kennedy, John Hargreaves, Graeme Blundell, Jeanie Drynan and Clare Binney.
